issues.description: Inner-artifact contradiction in the problem statement about the type of the Animal.name attribute: the UML diagram shows the attribute as name: String (problem_statement.md lines ~26-29), but the textual instructions explicitly require using StringBuilder for the name attribute (problem_statement.md line ~85). This conflicting specification can confuse students about which type to use when implementing getters, setters, and constructors.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the problem statement consistent: either (A) update the UML diagram to show name: StringBuilder to match the textual instruction, or (B) remove the textual instruction requiring StringBuilder and keep name as String. Ensure the text clearly specifies the expected field type so students implement the correct getter/setter signatures.

issues.description: Cross-artifact type mismatch between the problem statement and the solution implementation for Animal.name: the problem text requires using StringBuilder for the name attribute (problem_statement.md line ~85), but the provided solution implements Animal with a private String name field and String-based getter/setter (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Animal.java lines ~3-8). This inconsistency can mislead students about the intended implementation and cause confusion when comparing their work with the reference solution or tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the artifacts: either (A) update the solution (and any tests) to use StringBuilder for the Animal.name field (e.g., private StringBuilder name; provide appropriate constructor, getter, and setter signatures), or (B) change the problem statement to require a String name (removing the StringBuilder requirement). Prefer the option that matches the intended tests/grading expectations. If keeping StringBuilder, clarify whether getters/setters should expose StringBuilder or convert to/from String to avoid signature mismatches with test code.
